choices.text: Incomplete fusion between the first and second branchial arches
Defective closure of the external auditory canal
Remnant of the first pharyngeal pouch

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic by his parents with a complaint of recurrent swelling and pus discharge just in front of his right ear. The parents report that the swelling appears intermittently and sometimes drains spontaneously. There is no hearing loss or pain at present. On examination, a small pit is noted anterior to the tragus. The external auditory canal and tympanic membrane appear normal. Which of the following best explains the embryologic origin of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incomplete fusion between the first and second branchial arches

 

The tragus develops from the first branchial arch, whereas the rest of the auricle (pinna) develops from the second branchial arch. Improper fusion between these two arches during embryogenesis results in the formation of a preauricular sinus or pit. These are usually located anterior to the tragus and may become infected, causing recurrent abscesses. Surgical excision of the entire tract is the treatment of choice for recurrent infections, while asymptomatic cases can be observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistent second branchial cleft: Incorrect. A second branchial cleft cyst or sinus presents as a fluctuant swelling along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, usually in the lateral neck, not near the ear. It does not cause preauricular sinus formation.

 

Option C. Defective closure of the external auditory canal: Incorrect. This would lead to atresia or stenosis of the external auditory canal, often associated with conductive hearing loss, not a preauricular sinus.

 

Option D. Remnant of the first pharyngeal pouch: Incorrect. The first pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the Eustachian tube, middle ear cavity, and mastoid air cells. Defects here are not responsible for external sinus formation near the tragus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preauricular sinus results from improper fusion between the first and second branchial arches during auricular development; recurrent infections require surgical excision as definitive management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with pain and mild swelling over the tragus of his right ear following prolonged use of earphones. On examination, tenderness is localized to the tragus and adjacent helix. No external auditory canal infection is seen. Which nerve is most likely responsible for transmitting the pain sensation from this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), supplies sensory innervation to the tragus, crus of the helix, and adjacent helix. Hence, pain over the tragus and adjoining part of the pinna is carried via this nerve. It also provides sensation to the anterior part of the external auditory canal and temporal region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greater auricular nerve: Incorrect. The greater auricular nerve (from the cervical plexus, C2–C3) supplies the medial surface and posterior portion of the lateral surface of the auricle, including the area over the mastoid region. Pain limited to the tragus and helix is not mediated by this nerve.

 

Option C. Auricular branch of vagus nerve: Incorrect. Also called Arnold’s nerve, this branch of the vagus nerve (X) supplies the concha and antihelix, as well as part of the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane. Stimulation of this nerve may elicit a cough reflex (Arnold’s reflex), but it does not supply the tragus.

 

Option D. Lesser occipital nerve: Incorrect. The lesser occipital nerve (C2, cervical plexus) innervates the superior portion of the medial surface of the auricle and the skin of the scalp posterior to the auricle, not the tragal region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auriculotemporal nerve (branch of mandibular nerve, V3) supplies sensation to the tragus, crus of helix, and adjacent helix of the external ear.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with complaints of intermittent ear discharge and mild hearing loss in the right ear for the past 6 months following an episode of otitis media. On otoscopic examination, a small central perforation is seen in the tympanic membrane. The middle ear mucosa appears healthy. The surgeon plans a procedure to close the perforation and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane without disturbing ossicles. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical procedure for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringoplasty

 

Myringoplasty refers specifically to the surgical repair of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) when the middle ear mucosa and ossicular chain are intact and healthy. It involves grafting materials such as temporalis fascia or perichondrium to close the perforation, thus restoring the eardrum’s continuity and improving hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meatoplasty: Incorrect. Meatoplasty is a procedure performed to enlarge the cartilaginous portion of the external auditory canal, often done in conjunction with mastoidectomy to ensure adequate ventilation and easy postoperative cleaning. It is not used for tympanic membrane repair.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty: Incorrect. Tympanoplasty is a broader term referring to reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and/or ossicular chain to restore middle ear function. It is indicated when the ossicles are diseased or disrupted (e.g., in chronic suppurative otitis media with ossicular necrosis). Since this patient has an intact ossicular chain, myringoplasty alone is sufficient.

 

Option D. Otoplasty: Incorrect. Otoplasty refers to cosmetic or reconstructive surgery of the pinna (auricle), performed to correct deformities such as prominent ears or traumatic ear defects. It is unrelated to tympanic membrane or middle ear repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringoplasty is the surgical repair of the tympanic membrane alone, whereas tympanoplasty includes repair of both the tympanic membrane and middle ear structures.

choices.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media – tubotympanic type
Atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with painless ear discharge and progressive hearing loss in the left ear for 3 months. The discharge is non-foul-smelling and scanty. On otoscopic examination, multiple small perforations are seen in the tympanic membrane, and pale granulation tissue is visible in the middle ear. There is also a small postauricular swelling with facial weakness on the same side. There is no history of trauma or recent upper respiratory infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubercular otitis media

 

Tubercular otitis media (TOM) is a rare form of chronic otitis media caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.


Classical features include:

 

  • Painless otorrhea (discharge) that is typically scanty and non-foul-smelling
  • Multiple small perforations in the tympanic membrane that may later coalesce
  • Pale granulations or caseous necrosis in the middle ear
  • Early and severe hearing loss that is disproportionate to the appearance of the tympanic membrane
  • Facial nerve palsy or postauricular abscess may occur due to bone necrosis

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by acid-fast bacilli (AFB) demonstration, PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, or histopathology showing caseating granulomas.


Treatment involves antitubercular therapy (ATT) and, in some cases, surgical debridement if complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic suppurative otitis media – tubotympanic type: Incorrect.
This form usually presents with a central perforation and foul-smelling, mucopurulent discharge, often associated with pain or fever during acute exacerbations. Multiple perforations and painless discharge are not characteristic.

 

Option C. Atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media: Incorrect. This type involves attic perforation with cholesteatoma formation, leading to foul-smelling discharge, bone erosion, and complications such as mastoiditis or intracranial spread. Multiple small perforations are not typical.

 

Option D. Fungal otitis externa: Incorrect. Characterized by intense itching, ear fullness, and black or white fungal debris in the external auditory canal. Tympanic membrane perforation and facial palsy are not seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubercular otitis media presents with painless, scanty discharge, multiple tympanic membrane perforations, pale granulations, and early severe hearing loss, often complicated by facial palsy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old factory worker presents with complaints of progressive hardness of hearing in the right ear. He has a history of prolonged exposure to loud machinery noise at his workplace but denies ear discharge or pain. On examination, Rinne’s test is negative in the right ear and positive in the left ear. Weber’s test lateralizes to the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right conductive hearing loss

 

In Rinne’s test, a negative result (Bone conduction > Air conduction) indicates conductive hearing loss in that ear.


In Weber’s test, sound lateralizes to the affected ear in conductive hearing loss because background noise is less and bone conduction is perceived better.


Thus, Rinne negative on right + Weber to right = Right conductive hearing loss.

 

Although the patient has a history of noise exposure (which can cause sensorineural hearing loss), the tuning fork tests clearly indicate conductive pathology on the right side. This could represent mixed etiology or superimposed conductive component such as wax, otitis media, or ossicular chain defect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. If there were a left conductive loss, Weber would lateralize to the left, and Rinne would be negative on the left, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Right sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne remains positive (Air > Bone), and Weber lateralizes to the opposite ear (better-hearing ear). Therefore, this pattern doesn’t fit sensorineural hearing loss on the right.

 

Option D. Left sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. If the left ear had sensorineural hearing loss, Weber would lateralize to the right (better ear) as seen here, but Rinne would be positive bilaterally. Since Rinne is negative on the right, this combination rules out left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rinne’s test negative and Weber lateralized to the same ear, the diagnosis is conductive hearing loss in that ear.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with gradually progressive hearing loss and imbalance for the past few months. MRI of the internal auditory canal shows a small lesion arising from the inferior vestibular nerve, which is seen compressing the cochlear nerve. The patient denies ear discharge or pain. Which of the following types of hearing loss is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sensorineural hearing loss

 

A lesion arising from the inferior vestibular nerve, such as a vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma), can compress the cochlear nerve, leading to sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).


This loss is typically unilateral, progressive, and associated with tinnitus or imbalance. Since the cochlear nerve is part of the inner ear neural pathway, damage results in impaired sound perception and poor speech discrimination, characteristic of SNHL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. Conductive hearing loss occurs due to a problem in sound transmission through the external or middle ear (e.g., wax, otitis media, ossicular fixation). It is not caused by retrocochlear lesions such as vestibular schwannoma.

 

Option C. Mixed hearing loss: Incorrect. Mixed hearing loss involves both conductive and sensorineural components (e.g., chronic otitis media with labyrinthine involvement). In this case, only the cochlear nerve is compressed, so the loss is purely sensorineural.

 

Option D. No hearing loss: Incorrect. Although some very early lesions may present with isolated vestibular symptoms (vertigo, imbalance), once the cochlear nerve is compressed, hearing loss inevitably develops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Compression of the cochlear nerve by a lesion of the inferior vestibular nerve causes unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (as seen in vestibular schwannoma).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with gradual hearing loss in the right ear. On tuning fork testing, Rinne’s test is negative for the 256 Hz fork but positive for the 512 Hz fork on the right side. Weber’s test lateralizes to the right ear. The left ear shows normal results. What is the approximate degree of hearing loss in the right ear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15–30 dB

 

The Rinne test performed with tuning forks of different frequencies (256 Hz, 512 Hz, 1024 Hz) can provide an approximate estimate of the degree of conductive hearing loss based on which frequencies fail to be heard via air conduction.

 

  • Rinne negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz → ≈ 15–30 dB loss
  • Rinne negative for 256 Hz & 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz → ≈ 30–45 dB loss
  • Rinne negative for all (256, 512, 1024 Hz) → ≈ 45–60 dB loss

 

Because this patient has Rinne negative only for 256 Hz and positive for 512 Hz, the hearing loss corresponds to approximately 15–30 dB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10–15 dB: Incorrect. Such minimal loss would not cause a Rinne negative result even at low frequencies.

 

Option C. 30–45 dB: Incorrect. This degree of loss would make Rinne negative for both 256 Hz and 512 Hz forks, not just one.

 

Option D. 45–60 Db: Incorrect. Severe loss of this range produces Rinne negative for all tuning forks (256, 512, 1024 Hz).

 

Educational Objective:

 

If Rinne’s test is negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz, the approximate conductive hearing loss is 15–30 dB in that ear.

questions.text: Identify the PTA type:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right conductive hearing loss

 

In the audiogram, the red symbols represent the right ear (standard color coding: red = right, blue = left).


Here, air conduction thresholds are elevated (40–50 dB), while bone conduction thresholds are normal. The air–bone gap indicates that the problem lies in sound conduction through the external or middle ear, consistent with conductive hearing loss.

 

Typical causes include:

 

  • Wax impaction
  • Otitis media with effusion
  • Tympanic membrane perforation
  • Otosclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. There are no findings from the left ear shown in this audiogram. The red symbols correspond to the right ear, so this option is not correct.

 

Option C. Right sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. In sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), both air and bone conduction thresholds are elevated without an air–bone gap. In this case, the bone conduction remains normal, ruling out SNHL.

 

Option D. Left sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. Again, no data for the left ear are provided. Moreover, the pattern shown (normal bone, elevated air) indicates a conductive, not sensorineural, loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An air–bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on audiogram indicates a conductive hearing loss in the tested ear (right in this case).

questions.text: Otoscopic picture of a patient is shown. What is the audiogram pattern seen in the same patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 

 

 

The image shows a reddish glow behind an intact tympanic membrane, known as the Schwartze’s sign, which represents hypervascularity of the promontory due to active otosclerotic focus.
Otosclerosis is a disease of the bony labyrinth capsule, commonly involving the stapes footplate, causing progressive conductive hearing loss.

 

  • Audiogram finding: Conductive hearing loss with air–bone gap and characteristic Carhart’s notch (dip at 2 kHz in bone conduction).
  • Laterality: Since the image shows the right ear, the corresponding audiogram pattern would be that of right otosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Audiogram of Ménière’s disease: Incorrect. Ménière’s disease produces sensorineural hearing loss, typically fluctuating and affecting low frequencies first, associated with vertigo and tinnitus. There is no Schwartze’s sign or air–bone gap.

 

Option B. Audiogram of left otosclerosis: Incorrect. Although the audiometric pattern may resemble otosclerosis, the clinical image clearly shows right ear involvement, ruling out the left side.

 

Option C. Audiogram of noise-induced hearing loss: Incorrect. Noise-induced hearing loss shows a sensorineural pattern with a notch at 4 kHz, not a conductive loss. The tympanic membrane appears normal in such cases, without Schwartze’s sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwartze’s sign (reddish glow behind intact tympanic membrane) indicates active otosclerosis, which produces a conductive hearing loss with air–bone gap on the audiogram of the affected ear.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with pulsatile tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in her right ear. On otoscopic examination, a reddish mass is seen behind an intact tympanic membrane that pulsates synchronously with her pulse and blanches on pneumatic otoscopy. CT of the temporal bone shows obliteration of the caroticojugular spine, and MRI shows a “salt and pepper” appearance in the jugular foramen region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus jugulare

 

Glomus jugulare is a paraganglioma arising from the glomus cells around the jugular bulb.

 

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear, more common in females.
  • Clinical features:
    • Pulsatile tinnitus (synchronous with pulse)
    • Conductive hearing loss due to mass effect on ossicles
    • Rising sun sign: reddish reflex through intact tympanic membrane
    • Brown’s (Pulsation) sign: tumor blanches/pulsates on applying canal pressure
    • Aquino’s sign: blanching of mass on carotid artery compression
  • CT scan: shows Phelps sign — obliteration of caroticojugular spine, a bony ridge between the carotid canal and jugular bulb.
  • MRI: shows salt-and-pepper appearance due to interspersed areas of hemorrhage (salt) and flow voids (pepper).
  • Never biopsy because of the high risk of bleeding.
  • Treatment: Surgery, radiation, or preoperative embolization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus tympanicum: Incorrect. Arises from glomus bodies over the promontory, smaller and confined to the middle ear. Produces similar symptoms (hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus) but does not extend to the jugular foramen, and Phelps sign (CT) is not seen.

 

Option C. Hemangioma of the middle ear: Incorrect. Though vascular, it is rare and lacks the characteristic signs such as Phelps, Aquino, or Brown’s sign. Also, hemangiomas show a different radiologic pattern without salt-and-pepper appearance.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: Incorrect. A non-vascular, destructive lesion causing foul-smelling discharge and hearing loss, but no pulsatile tinnitus or vascular signs. On otoscopy, it appears as a retraction pocket with keratin debris, not a red mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomus jugulare is a highly vascular paraganglioma arising from glomus cells around the jugular bulb, showing Phelps sign on CT (obliteration of caroticojugular spine) and salt-and-pepper appearance on MRI, with pulsatile tinnitus and Brown’s sign clinically.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toruz tubarius

 

The torus tubarius is a prominent elevation on the lateral wall of the nasopharynx formed by the cartilaginous end of the Eustachian (auditory) tube.

 

  • It appears as a smooth, rounded bulge above and behind the tubal opening on nasal endoscopy.
  • The fossa of Rosenmüller (pharyngeal recess) lies posterior to the torus tubarius, and it is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • The salpingopharyngeal fold descends downward from the torus tubarius.
  • Functionally, the torus helps in equalizing middle ear pressure during swallowing and yawning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fossa of Rosenmüller: Incorrect. This is a recess or depression posterior to the torus tubarius, not the bulge itself. It is a potential site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which can cause ear blockage or serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube obstruction.

 

Option C. Opening of the Eustachian tube: Incorrect. The opening of the Eustachian tube lies below and anterior to the torus tubarius. It appears as a slit-like orifice leading into the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube.

 

Option D. Posterior pharyngeal wall: Incorrect. This lies medially and posteriorly in the nasopharynx, forming the posterior limit of the cavity. It is not the structure shown or marked in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The torus tubarius is the prominent cartilaginous elevation surrounding the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube on the lateral nasopharyngeal wall.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with ear pain, fever, and decreased hearing in his right ear for the past two days following an episode of upper respiratory tract infection. Otoscopic examination reveals a congested, bulging tympanic membrane with loss of the light reflex and obliteration of handle of malleus as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Otitis Media

 

The image shows a congested, bulging tympanic membrane with loss of translucency and light reflex, typical of acute otitis media (AOM).

 

  • Pathophysiology: Most often follows viral upper respiratory infection leading to Eustachian tube dysfunction and secondary bacterial infection (common organisms: Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Ear pain (otalgia)
    • Fever
    • Conductive hearing loss
    • In children, irritability and tugging of ear
  • Otoscopic findings:
    • Congested and bulging tympanic membrane
    • Loss of landmarks (malleus not visible)
    • Loss of cone of light
    • May progress to spontaneous rupture with purulent discharge

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otitis Media with Effusion: Incorrect. This condition, also called serous otitis media, shows a retracted, dull, and amber-colored tympanic membrane with visible air-fluid levels or bubbles, not a bulging red membrane. It is non-suppurative and often follows acute otitis media.

 

Option C. Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media: Incorrect. This shows a perforated tympanic membrane with purulent discharge and often mucosal changes. The tympanic membrane is not intact or acutely bulging as in this image.

 

Option D. Otitis Externa: Incorrect. In otitis externa, the external auditory canal is inflamed, edematous, and tender. The tympanic membrane is normal or secondarily inflamed, but not bulging. Pain worsens on moving the pinna.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bulging, congested tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks and light reflex on otoscopy is diagnostic of acute otitis media.

choices.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media – tubotympanic type
Chronic suppurative otitis media – atticoantral type

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with intermittent foul-smelling ear discharge and hearing loss in the right ear for 8 months. The discharge is scanty but persistent despite repeated courses of antibiotics. He denies pain or fever. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket with perforation in the pars flaccida (attic) region, with keratin debris visible beneath it, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic suppurative otitis media – atticoantral type

 

This is the unsafe type of CSOM, also called epitympanic or squamous disease, because it commonly harbors cholesteatoma.

 

  • Site: Pars flaccida (attic) or posterosuperior quadrant of pars tensa.
  • Key features:
    • Foul-smelling scanty discharge
    • Retraction or perforation in attic region
    • Keratin debris or cholesteatoma flakes seen under otoscopy
    • Progressive conductive hearing loss due to ossicular erosion
    • Risk of complications (facial palsy, labyrinthitis, meningitis, brain abscess).
  • Treatment: Surgical — Modified Radical Mastoidectomy (MRM) or Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy to eradicate disease and create a safe, dry ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM – tubotympanic type: Incorrect.


This is the safe type of chronic otitis media.

 

  • Site: Central perforation in pars tensa.
  • Discharge: Mucopurulent, non-foul smelling.
  • No cholesteatoma or bone erosion.

 

Option C. Acute otitis media: Incorrect. Presents with acute pain, fever, and bulging red tympanic membrane; not with long-standing discharge or attic retraction.

 

Option D. Otitis externa — Incorrect. Characterized by diffuse inflammation of external auditory canal, with severe pain on tragal or pinna movement, not attic perforation or keratin debris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atticoantral disease (unsafe CSOM) involves perforation or retraction in the pars flaccida (attic) with cholesteatoma formation, causing foul-smelling discharge and hearing loss, and requires surgical management (MRM) to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He was not wearing a helmet and sustained a head injury after falling from his bike. On examination, he is conscious and oriented. There is ecchymosis over the mastoid region (behind the ear), but no active bleeding. Otoscopic examination shows a small amount of bloody discharge from the external auditory canal. Which of the following skull fractures is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle cranial fossa fracture

 

Battle’s sign refers to ecchymosis over the mastoid process, resulting from extravasation of blood along the path of the posterior auricular artery following a fracture of the petrous part of the temporal bone—a component of the middle cranial fossa.

 

  • This type of fracture is associated with basal skull fracture, often accompanied by:
    • Hemotympanum (blood behind tympanic membrane)
    • CSF otorrhea (if dura torn)
    • Facial nerve palsy (if facial canal involved)
    • Hearing loss (conductive or sensorineural depending on site)
      Thus, Battle’s sign is a late but important indicator of a basal skull fracture involving the middle cranial fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cranial fossa fracture: Incorrect. This leads to raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis) and CSF rhinorrhea due to cribiform plate fracture, not Battle’s sign.

 

Option C. Posterior cranial fossa fracture: Incorrect. These fractures may present with cerebellar signs or cranial nerve IX–XI deficits, but Battle’s sign is not a typical feature.

 

Option D. Parietal bone fracture: Incorrect. Presents with localized scalp swelling and tenderness, possibly overlying hematoma, but does not cause mastoid ecchymosis because it does not involve the base of the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle’s sign (postauricular ecchymosis) is a clinical marker of a middle cranial fossa fracture involving the petrous part of the temporal bone, often associated with hemotympanum, CSF otorrhea, and facial nerve injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with high-grade fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. He has a history of chronic suppurative otitis media with intermittent ear discharge for several years. On examination, he is febrile and drowsy. Fundus shows papilledema. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The CT image shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema in the temporal lobe, which is the most common site for otogenic brain abscess (secondary to chronic suppurative otitis media).

 

  • Etiology: Spread of infection from the middle ear or mastoid through bone or venous channels.
  • Symptoms: Headache, fever, vomiting, altered sensorium, focal neurological signs (e.g., aphasia, seizures), and signs of raised intracranial pressure (papilledema, bradycardia, hypertension).
  • CT findings: Well-defined ring-enhancing lesion with central hypodensity and surrounding edema.
  • Management: IV antibiotics + surgical drainage of abscess and ear disease (mastoidectomy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Incorrect. Cerebellar abscess is another complication of chronic otitis media, especially when the posterior fossa is involved.

 

  • Clinical features: Ataxia, nystagmus, intention tremor, and signs of raised intracranial pressure.
  • The CT scan here shows a temporal lobe lesion, not a posterior fossa (cerebellar) lesion.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Incorrect. Subdural abscess (empyema) appears as a crescent-shaped extra-axial collection and not a ring-enhancing parenchymal lesion. It usually spreads from sinusitis rather than otitis media.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Incorrect. Meningitis presents with diffuse meningeal enhancement and CSF abnormalities (neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein). It does not form a localized ring-enhancing lesion on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media, presenting with fever, headache, altered sensorium, and a ring-enhancing lesion on CT, requiring urgent antibiotic therapy and surgical drainage.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the utricle develop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pars superior

 

The otic vesicle (otocyst) differentiates into two parts — pars superior and pars inferior:

 

  • Pars superior gives rise to the utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic duct/sac — all related to balance and spatial orientation.
  • Pars inferior gives rise to the saccule and cochlear duct (organ of Corti) — structures associated with hearing and linear acceleration detection.
    Therefore, the utricle, being part of the vestibular system, develops from pars superior of the otic vesicle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacculus anterior: Incorrect. ,There is no separate “anterior sacculus” in embryologic terminology. The saccule itself arises from the pars inferior, not the superior division.

 

Option B. Sacculus posterior: Incorrect. Similarly, the term “posterior sacculus” is anatomically inaccurate. The saccule as a whole forms from pars inferior, not from the region giving rise to the utricle.

 

Option D. Pars inferior: Incorrect. The pars inferior forms the saccule and cochlear duct, both related to sound perception, not the utricle or semicircular canals (which are balance organs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic duct develop from the pars superior of the otic vesicle, while the saccule and cochlear duct arise from the pars inferior.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in lower frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Helicotrema

 

The helicotrema is the apical end of the cochlea, where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli communicate.

 

  • The apex of the cochlea corresponds to low-frequency sound perception, while the base corresponds to high-frequency sound perception.
  • Hence, when the apical portion of the basilar membrane is affected, low-frequency hearing loss occurs.
  • The helicotrema lies adjacent to this apical region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: Incorrect. The modiolus is the central bony core of the cochlea that contains spiral ganglion cells and the cochlear nerve fibers. It lies medially within the cochlear turns, closer to the base, not the apex (where low-frequency sounds are detected).

 

Option B. Stria vascularis: Incorrect. The stria vascularis is located along the lateral wall of the cochlear duct, responsible for maintaining endolymph ionic composition (high K+) and generating the endocochlear potential. It is not specifically localized to the apical region nor involved directly in frequency discrimination.

 

Option C. Oval window: Incorrect. The oval window lies at the base of the cochlea and is connected to the stapes footplate of the middle ear. It transmits sound vibrations to the perilymph of the scala vestibuli. Damage near the oval window affects high-frequency hearing, not low-frequency sounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The helicotrema, located at the apex of the cochlea, is adjacent to the region of the basilar membrane that detects low-frequency sounds; thus, apical cochlear damage results in low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A histopathology slide of a cerebellopontine angle tumor is shown below (H&E stain). The section shows interlacing spindle-shaped cells with elongated nuclei arranged in alternating hypercellular (Antoni A) and hypocellular (Antoni B) areas, with Verocay bodies (palisading nuclei around acellular zones). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acoustic neuroma (Vestibular schwannoma)

 

  • Histopathology: Characterized by Antoni A and Antoni B areas.
    • Antoni A: Highly cellular regions with spindle-shaped Schwann cells arranged in palisades and whorls, forming Verocay bodies (rows of aligned nuclei separated by eosinophilic zones).
    • Antoni B: Loosely arranged, hypocellular areas with vacuolated cytoplasm.
  • Origin: Arises from Schwann cells of the vestibular division of the 8th cranial nerve (inferior vestibular nerve).
  • Site: Cerebellopontine angle, extending from internal auditory canal.
  • Clinical features:
    • Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss,
    • Tinnitus,
    • Loss of corneal reflex (trigeminal nerve compression),
    • Facial numbness or weakness (facial nerve compression),
    • Ataxia (cerebellar involvement).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meningioma: Incorrect.

 

  • Originates from arachnoid cap cells.
  • Histology shows whorled pattern, psammoma bodies, and syncytial arrangement, not Antoni A/B areas.
  • May also occur at cerebellopontine angle but typically shows broad dural attachment (dural tail) on imaging.

 

Option C. Neurofibroma: Incorrect.

 

  • Composed of spindle cells with wavy nuclei within a myxoid background.
  • Lacks the biphasic Antoni pattern and Verocay bodies.
  • Arises from peripheral nerve sheath, but involves both Schwann cells and fibroblasts (unlike schwannoma, which is purely Schwann cell-derived).

 

Option D. Glioblastoma multiforme: Incorrect.

 

  • Highly malignant astrocytic tumor showing necrosis, vascular proliferation, and pleomorphic astrocytes.
  • Occurs within brain parenchyma (not at cerebellopontine angle) and lacks spindle cell morphology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) shows Antoni A and B areas with Verocay bodies on histopathology and arises from Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve at the cerebellopontine angle, causing unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and cranial nerve compression.

questions.text: Name the manoeuvre shown in image
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Semont 

 

The Semont (Liberatory) maneuver is a repositioning procedure used in Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), particularly for posterior semicircular canal involvement.

 

  • It works by dislodging otoconia (canaliths) from the cupula or semicircular canal and moving them back into the utricle.
  • Steps:
    1. The patient sits upright (head turned 45° to the unaffected side).
    2. Rapidly moved to the affected side (head still turned upward).
    3. After ~30 seconds, the patient is quickly moved to the opposite side without changing head orientation (now facing downward).
    4. Finally, the patient returns to the sitting position.
  • It is faster than the Epley maneuver but may cause transient vertigo during the movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley maneuver: Incorrect. Also used for posterior canal BPPV, but involves sequential head rotations (45° each) while the patient is reclined to move the canaliths through the posterior canal back into the utricle. The image shown corresponds to Semont, not Epley, because it involves rapid movement from one side-lying position to the other.

 

Option B. Heimlich maneuver: Incorrect. This is a first-aid procedure for choking, where subdiaphragmatic abdominal thrusts are applied to expel a foreign body from the airway. It has no role in vestibular disorders.

 

Option C. Cottle maneuver: Incorrect. Used in nasal obstruction evaluation, where the cheek is lifted laterally to assess for nasal valve collapse. It has no relation to vertigo or otolith repositioning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Semont maneuver is a liberatory repositioning technique for posterior canal BPPV, performed by rapidly moving the patient from side to side to dislodge otoliths from the cupula and return them to the utricle, thereby relieving vertigo.

questions.text: Identify the part of cochlear implant marked as '?'
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Receiver stimulator

 

  • The receiver–stimulator is the internal component of the cochlear implant, surgically placed under the skin behind the ear.
  • It receives electrical signals transmitted from the external transmitter and converts them into electrical impulses.
  • These impulses are delivered via intracochlear electrodes inserted into the cochlea to directly stimulate the auditory nerve fibers, bypassing damaged hair cells.
  • This component is essential for converting sound into neural signals that the brain can interpret as hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grounding electrode: Incorrect. The grounding electrode (reference electrode) stabilizes the electrical potential of the system and prevents current buildup, but it is not the component responsible for stimulation or signal reception.

 

Option B. External transmitter: Incorrect.

 

  • The external transmitter is the outer magnetic coil that sends coded signals (via radiofrequency) from the external speech processor to the implanted receiver–stimulator through the skin.
  • It lies outside the skull, not implanted beneath the skin as shown in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: Incorrect.

 

  • The electrode array is the wire-like component that runs from the receiver–stimulator into the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • It delivers the electrical impulses to the spiral ganglion cells, but it is not the receiver unit marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The receiver–stimulator of a cochlear implant is the internal implanted unit that receives signals from the external transmitter and sends them via the electrode array to stimulate the auditory nerve, restoring hearing in cases of severe sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with acute vertigo, nausea, and imbalance following a recent viral illness. There is no hearing loss or tinnitus. On performing the Head Impulse Test (HIT), when the examiner rapidly turns the patient’s head to the left, the patient’s eyes move briefly with the head and then make a corrective saccade back to the target. Which of the following best describes the direction of the saccade in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right on left head rotation

 

Concept:


The Head Impulse Test (HIT) evaluates the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) — the reflex that keeps the eyes fixed on a target during head movement.

 

  • In a normal person, when the head is turned quickly to one side, the VOR causes the eyes to move in the opposite direction at the same speed — maintaining fixation.
  • In unilateral vestibular neuritis, the VOR is defective on the side of the lesion.

 

Step-by-step for this case (Left Vestibular Neuritis):

 

  1. The left vestibular nerve is damaged → no vestibular input when the head moves toward the left.
  2. The right (normal) vestibular nerve still sends a signal of head rotation to the right.
  3. As a result, the eyes briefly move with the head (leftward) instead of compensating.
  4. To refixate the target, a corrective (catch-up) saccade occurs toward the right, i.e. opposite to the head movement direction.

 

Hence,

 

  • Lesion side: Left
  • Head rotation: Left
  • Saccade direction: Right

 

Because of left vestibular hypofunction, the eyes fail to stay fixed and a rightward corrective saccade occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left on left head rotation: Incorrect. Saccade direction is always opposite to the head rotation in a positive HIT.

 

Option B. Left on right head rotation: Incorrect. Turning toward the healthy (right) ear produces a normal VOR, so no saccade is seen.

 

Option D. Right on right head rotation: Incorrect. A rightward saccade on right rotation would indicate right vestibular neuritis, not left.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In left vestibular neuritis, the Head Impulse Test shows a rightward corrective saccade on left head rotation, indicating defective vestibulo-ocular reflex on the left side.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the ENT emergency department after a road traffic accident with complaints of nasal obstruction and nasal deformity. On examination, there is a depressed nasal septal fracture with deviation toward the right side. There is no septal hematoma. The ENT surgeon plans to perform closed reduction of the septal fracture under local anesthesia. Which of the following instruments is most appropriate for the reduction of the depressed septal fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asch forceps

 

  • Asch forceps are double-bladed nasal forceps specifically designed for the reduction of septal fractures, especially depressed (buckled) fractures.
  • They are introduced on both sides of the septum and then used to elevate and realign the displaced cartilaginous or bony septum.
  • The blades are narrow and curved, designed to minimize trauma to the mucosa.
  • Commonly used in post-traumatic nasal septal dislocation or depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Walsham forceps: Incorrect.

 

  • Walsham forceps are used for reduction of displaced nasal bones, not the septum.
  • They are strong, broad-bladed forceps used externally to elevate and align nasal bone fragments.
  • In this case, since the septum (not nasal bone) is fractured, Asch forceps are preferred.

 

Option C. Luc forceps: Incorrect.

 

  • Luc forceps are cutting and grasping forceps used mainly for removing nasal polyps, antral tissue, or during FESS procedures.
  • They are not designed for fracture manipulation or bone reduction.

 

Option D. Killian forceps: Incorrect.

 

  • Killian forceps are used for removing nasal spurs or bony fragments and for sinus surgeries, not for fracture reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asch forceps are specifically used for the reduction of depressed nasal septal fractures, whereas Walsham forceps are used for nasal bone fracture reduction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of nasal whistling and crusting for the past few months. She had a history of septal surgery (SMR) 2 years ago. On anterior rhinoscopy, a through-and-through defect is seen in the anterior cartilaginous septum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septal perforation

 

  • A septal perforation is a through-and-through defect of the nasal septum involving both mucosal layers and the intervening cartilage or bone.
  • Most common site: Anterior quadrilateral cartilage.
  • Common causes:
    • Trauma (especially iatrogenic after SMR or septoplasty)
    • Chronic nasal spray use (steroids, decongestants)
    • Infections: Syphilis (bony septal perforation), leprosy
    • Autoimmune/systemic diseases: Wegener’s granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis), sarcoidosis, SLE
  • Symptoms:
    • Whistling noise during breathing (if small perforation)
    • Crusting and dryness (if large/anterior)
    • Recurrent epistaxis due to inflammation at margins
  • Management:
    • Asymptomatic: Observation
    • Symptomatic: Silastic button, surgical closure (free grafts/pedicled flaps)
    • If whistling predominant: Enlargement of perforation to stop the whistle

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septal deviation: Incorrect. Refers to bending or displacement of the septum causing nasal obstruction, but there is no defect or communication between the two nasal cavities.

 

Option B. Septal hematoma: Incorrect.

 

  • Occurs after nasal trauma, presenting with bilateral bluish swelling of the septum due to subperichondrial blood collection.
  • Untreated cases may lead to abscess or cartilage necrosis, which in turn can cause septal perforation, but not the initial presentation here.

 

Option D. Rhinolith: Incorrect.

 

  • Refers to a calcified mass around a foreign body within the nasal cavity, not a septal defect.
  • Presents with unilateral nasal discharge and foul smell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A septal perforation is a through-and-through defect of the nasal septum, most commonly in the anterior quadrilateral cartilage, caused by trauma (especially iatrogenic), nasal sprays, or autoimmune/infectious diseases, presenting with whistling, crusting, and recurrent epistaxis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the ENT emergency with recurrent profuse epistaxis from the posterior nasal cavity. He has been hypertensive for several years and recently underwent unsuccessful anterior and posterior nasal packing. The ENT surgeon now plans for arterial ligation to control the bleeding. Which of the following arteries is most appropriate to ligate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sphenopalatine artery

 

  • The sphenopalatine artery, a terminal branch of the maxillary artery (from external carotid system), is the main arterial supply of the posterior nasal cavity.
  • It supplies the posterior part of the nasal septum and lateral nasal wall, and its rupture leads to posterior epistaxis, which is often profuse and difficult to control with packing.
  • In such cases, sphenopalatine artery ligation (usually done endoscopically) is the treatment of choice.
  • This effectively controls bleeding in the majority of intractable epistaxis cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior ethmoidal artery: Incorrect.

 

  • This artery arises from the ophthalmic artery (internal carotid system) and supplies the anterior-superior part of the nasal cavity.
  • It is responsible for anterior epistaxis, particularly from Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus).
  • Ligation of this artery is done only when bleeding arises from the anterior superior nasal cavity, not from posterior sources.

 

Option B. Posterior ethmoidal artery: Incorrect.

 

  • Also a branch of the ophthalmic artery, it supplies the posterior-superior portion of the nasal roof and upper septum, a less common site for epistaxis.
  • It is considered for ligation only in rare refractory cases of superior nasal bleeding.

 

Option D. Facial artery: Incorrect.

 

  • The facial artery gives rise to the superior labial artery, which contributes to Kiesselbach’s plexus (anterior nasal septum).
  • It may be ligated when bleeding arises from anterior nasal sources or when combined anterior and posterior ligation is needed.
  • However, in posterior epistaxis, sphenopalatine artery ligation is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In posterior epistaxis refractory to nasal packing, the sphenopalatine artery (terminal branch of the maxillary artery) is the most appropriate artery to ligate, as it supplies the posterior nasal cavity where most severe bleeding originates.

questions.text: Identify the blue coloured sinus in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethmoid 

 

  • The ethmoid sinuses (highlighted in blue) are a group of small air cells located between the nose and the orbit, within the ethmoid bone.
  • They lie medial to the orbit and lateral to the nasal cavity.
  • On CT imaging, the ethmoid air cells appear as multiple small compartments, unlike the single, large cavities of the maxillary or sphenoid sinuses.
  • Clinical correlation:
    • Ethmoid sinusitis can cause medial orbital pain and tenderness, and complications may include orbital cellulitis (due to the thin lamina papyracea).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxillary sinus: Incorrect.

 

  • The maxillary sinus is the largest paranasal sinus and is located below the orbits in the maxilla.
  • On CT, it appears as a large, pyramid-shaped cavity inferior to the eyes.
  • It is most commonly involved in sinus infections, but in this image, the area below the orbit is not highlighted.

 

Option B. Frontal sinus: Incorrect.

 

  • The frontal sinus lies above the orbit, within the frontal bone, and appears on CT as an air-filled cavity above the eyes.
  • It is not the blue-colored area seen in this axial CT image (which is taken below the level of the frontal sinus).

 

Option D. Sphenoid sinus: Incorrect.

 

  • The sphenoid sinus lies posterior to the nasal cavity and below the sella turcica.
  • It is visible as a single, midline cavity in the posterior skull base (green in the image), not the blue region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On CT imaging, the ethmoid sinus appears as multiple small air cells between the nasal cavity and orbit, distinguishing it from the larger maxillary, frontal, and sphenoid sinuses.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of sinusitis and productive cough since adolescence. He and his wife have been unable to conceive for 5 years. Semen analysis shows azoospermia with obstructed epididymal ducts, while a CT scan of the chest reveals bilateral bronchiectasis. There is no situs inversus on imaging. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Young syndrome

 

  • Young syndrome is characterized by the triad of:
    1. Recurrent sinusitis
    2. Bronchiectasis
    3. Male infertility due to obstructive azoospermia (epididymal blockage)
  • The respiratory symptoms resemble those of Kartagener syndrome but without situs inversus.
  • Pathophysiology: inspissated mucus obstructs the epididymis and respiratory tract.
  • Ciliary structure and function are normal (unlike in Kartagener syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kartagener syndrome: Incorrect.

 

  • A subtype of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD).
  • Presents with recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (dextrocardia).
  • Infertility occurs due to immotile sperm caused by defective dynein arms in cilia.
  • In this question, there is no situs inversus and sperm immotility is not described — pointing to Young syndrome instead.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Incorrect.

 

  • Caused by CFTR gene mutation, leading to thick, viscous secretions in the lungs and reproductive tract.
  • Causes bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, pancreatic insufficiency, and azoospermia due to congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens (CBAVD).
  • Pancreatic symptoms and steatorrhea are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Primary ciliary dyskinesia: Incorrect.

 

  • Includes Kartagener syndrome as a variant.
  • Due to dynein arm defect, causing immotile cilia → defective mucociliary clearance and male infertility due to immotile sperm.
  • Again, ciliary structure is normal in Young syndrome, which distinguishes it from this disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Young syndrome presents with recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and male infertility due to obstructive azoospermia, but without situs inversus and with normal ciliary function, distinguishing it from Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male, recently recovered from COVID-19 treated with corticosteroids, presents with facial pain, nasal congestion, and blackish nasal discharge. On examination, there is periorbital swelling, ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and decreased vision in the right eye. Nasal endoscopy reveals black necrotic tissue over the middle turbinate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis

 

  • Etiology: Caused by Mucor, Rhizopus, or Absidia species — angioinvasive fungi found in soil and decaying matter.
  • Risk factors:
    • Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
    • Immunosuppression (corticosteroid therapy, post-COVID infection, hematologic malignancy, organ transplant).
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Fungal hyphae invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis (hence black eschar).
    • Spread from nasal mucosa → paranasal sinuses → orbit → cavernous sinus → brain.
  • Clinical features:
    • Blackish nasal discharge or eschar over middle turbinate
    • Facial pain, periorbital edema, proptosis
    • Cranial nerve palsies (especially III, IV, VI due to orbital apex involvement)
    • Decreased or loss of vision
  • Diagnosis:
    • KOH mount or biopsy showing broad, aseptate, right-angle branching hyphae
    • MRI/CT showing sinus invasion, orbital or intracranial extension
  • Treatment:
    • Urgent surgical debridement of necrotic tissue
    • Systemic Amphotericin B (liposomal formulation preferred)
    • Strict glycemic control and withdrawal of immunosuppressants

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic fungal sinusitis: Incorrect.

 

  • Typically affects immunocompetent young adults with nasal polyposis and allergic mucin in sinuses.
  • No tissue invasion or necrosis, and black eschar is absent.

 

Option C. Bacterial orbital cellulitis: Incorrect.

 

  • Presents with pain, swelling, proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, but without black necrosis or cranial nerve palsies.
  • Usually secondary to ethmoid sinusitis by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus.
  • Does not show fungal hyphae or angioinvasion on histopathology.

 

Option D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Incorrect.

 

  • Can cause periorbital edema, ophthalmoplegia, and vision loss, but is typically secondary to facial or sinus infection spreading via veins.
  • There is no black necrotic eschar or fungal invasion.
  • MRI/MRV shows thrombosis of the cavernous sinus, not sinus necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is an angioinvasive fungal infection seen in diabetic or immunocompromised patients, characterized by black nasal eschar, cranial nerve palsies, and tissue necrosis, requiring urgent surgical debridement and Amphotericin B therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with gradually progressive, nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. He gives a history of facial trauma due to a road traffic accident 15 years ago. The CT scan of the paranasal sinuses (shown below) reveals a well-defined expansile cystic lesion involving the left frontal sinus, causing erosion of the sinus walls and displacement of the globe downward and outward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

  • A mucocele is a chronic, expansile cystic lesion of a paranasal sinus resulting from obstruction of the sinus ostium, leading to accumulation of mucus and gradual bone erosion.
  • Frontal sinus is the most common site, followed by the ethmoid sinus.
  • Etiology: Often secondary to trauma, infection, or previous sinus surgery, leading to blockage of drainage.
  • Clinical features:
    • Slowly progressive nonaxial proptosis (usually downward and outward if frontal sinus involved)
    • Frontal headache, facial swelling, or nasal obstruction
  • Imaging (CT):
    • Well-defined, expansile lesion with thinning and erosion of the frontal sinus walls
    • Fluid density or mucus-filled cavity
    • May cause displacement of the orbit
  • Treatment: Endoscopic marsupialization or drainage (frontal sinusotomy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningioma: Incorrect.

 

  • Intracranial tumor arising from meningothelial cells of the dura.
  • Causes axial proptosis and hyperostosis of bone, not cystic expansion.
  • CT shows a solid enhancing mass, not a cystic lesion with bone erosion.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect.

 

  • Benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor of adolescent males.
  • Arises from the sphenopalatine foramen region.
  • Presents with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction, not delayed post-traumatic proptosis.
  • CT/MRI shows a highly vascular mass in the nasopharynx, not the frontal sinus.

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of orbit: Incorrect.

 

  • Also known as idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome.
  • Presents with painful proptosis, chemosis, and restricted eye movements of acute onset.
  • CT shows diffuse orbital inflammation, not a sinus-based cystic lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A frontal mucocele is an expansile cystic lesion of the frontal sinus caused by obstruction of sinus drainage, leading to bony erosion and nonaxial proptosis, often following trauma or chronic sinusitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a chronic smoker and teacher, presents with hoarseness of voice for 3 months. On direct laryngoscopy, an irregular patch is noted over the middle third of the right vocal cord. Before taking a biopsy, the ENT surgeon applies a stain over the lesion on the table using an endoscope to identify suspicious malignant areas. Which of the following stains is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravital stain (Toluidine blue)

 

  • Toluidine blue is a basic metachromatic dye used as a supravital stain during endoscopic laryngoscopy.
  • It preferentially stains nucleic acids, binding strongly to DNA and RNA in areas of high mitotic activity, such as malignant and dysplastic cells.
  • When applied to the laryngeal mucosa, malignant lesions take up the dye and appear dark royal blue, while normal epithelium remains unstained or pale.
  • This helps the surgeon identify the most suspicious site for biopsy, reducing the chance of false negatives.
  • Hence, biopsy is targeted and less tissue damage occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Silver nitrate stain: Incorrect.

 

  • Used in histopathology to demonstrate fungal organisms, reticulin fibers, and spirochetes.
  • Not used in vivo during laryngoscopy.

 

Option C. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E): Incorrect.

 

  • H&E is a routine histological stain used after biopsy for microscopic evaluation.
  • It cannot be used on the table or on living mucosa.

 

Option D. Congo red stain: Incorrect.

 

  • Used for identifying amyloid deposits (apple-green birefringence under polarized light).
  • Has no role in vocal cord or malignancy screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue, a supravital stain, is applied during laryngoscopy to identify malignant or dysplastic areas of the vocal cords that take up the blue dye due to increased nucleic acid content, guiding targeted biopsy and early diagnosis of laryngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify marked structure (black arrow):
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vallecula

 

  • The vallecula is a depression or space between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis.
  • It is formed by the median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds.
  • On a lateral neck X-ray, it appears as a cup-shaped air-filled shadow above the epiglottis.
  • Clinically, the vallecula is the site where the tip of a laryngoscope blade (Macintosh) is placed during orotracheal intubation to lift the epiglottis indirectly and visualize the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyriform fossa: Incorrect.

 

  • Located on either side of the laryngeal inlet, within the hypopharynx.
  • It appears as a pair of lateral air pockets on an X-ray, not in the midline.
  • Common site for foreign body impaction.

 

Option B. Thyroid cartilage: Incorrect.

 

  • The largest cartilage of the larynx, forming the laryngeal prominence (Adam’s apple).
  • Seen as a radio-opaque shadow (not air-filled) on the lateral neck X-ray.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: Incorrect.

 

  • Appears as a curved, leaf-like soft tissue density located just posterior to the vallecula.
  • In acute epiglottitis, it becomes swollen, producing the classic “thumb sign” on lateral neck radiographs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vallecula is a midline depression between the base of the tongue and epiglottis, appearing as a cup-shaped air shadow on lateral neck X-ray, and serves as the site for laryngoscope blade placement during intubation.

choices.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman underwent total thyroidectomy for multinodular goiter. Postoperatively, she complains of hoarseness of voice but has no respiratory distress. Laryngoscopic examination reveals that one vocal cord is immobile in the paramedian position while the opposite cord moves normally. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

  • Injury to one recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) leads to unilateral vocal cord paralysis.
  • The paralyzed cord lies in the paramedian position, resulting in hoarseness due to incomplete glottic closure during phonation.
  • Respiration remains normal because the opposite cord abducts adequately.
  • This is the most common nerve injured during thyroid surgery due to its close relationship with the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve: Incorrect.

 

  • Injury to the external branch affects the cricothyroid muscle, leading to inability to produce high-pitched sounds but not hoarseness or airway obstruction.

 

Option C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve: Incorrect.

 

  • Causes bilateral vocal cord paralysis in paramedian position, resulting in airway obstruction and stridor, often requiring tracheostomy.
  • The question describes no respiratory distress, ruling this out.

 

Option D. Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve: Incorrect.

 

  • Provides sensory innervation above the vocal cords.
  • Injury leads to loss of cough reflex and aspiration risk, not hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during thyroidectomy leads to hoarseness with one vocal cord fixed in the paramedian position, while bilateral injury causes airway obstruction due to failure of abduction of both cords.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of prolonged intubation following pneumonia presents with progressive inspiratory stridor and voice changes. A direct laryngoscopy reveals subglottic narrowing. The airway narrowing involves approximately 75% of the lumen. Based on Cotton-Myer grading, what is the grade of subglottic stenosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade 3

 

  • Severe narrowing (71–99%) producing inspiratory and expiratory stridor at rest.

 

Cotton-Myer Grading of Subglottic Stenosis:

 

 

  • In this case, ~75% obstruction corresponds to Grade 3, causing significant airway compromise and stridor even at rest.
  • Common causes include prolonged endotracheal intubation, trauma, laryngeal infection, or autoimmune diseases (e.g., Wegener’s granulomatosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1: Incorrect. Mild narrowing (≤50%) usually asymptomatic or presents with stridor only on exertion.

 

Option B. Grade 2: Incorrect. Moderate narrowing (51–70%), typically associated with mild inspiratory stridor.

 

Option D. Grade 4: Incorrect. Complete occlusion (100%) of airway leading to immediate respiratory distress requiring emergency tracheostomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cotton-Myer grading classifies subglottic stenosis based on the percentage of airway obstruction—Grade 1 (0–50%), Grade 2 (51–70%), Grade 3 (71–99%), and Grade 4 (100%)—with Grade 3 commonly seen in post-intubation cases presenting with stridor at rest.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents 3 months after surgery for laryngeal carcinoma. He has permanent loss of voice, but can breathe comfortably through an opening in the lower neck as shown in the image. There is no connection between the airway and oral cavity. Which of the following procedures was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

  • In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx (including vocal cords) is surgically removed.
  • The trachea is brought out as a permanent stoma in the lower neck, creating a separate airway passage (no continuity with mouth or nose).
  • Speech is lost since vocal cords are excised, though rehabilitation may include electrolarynx or tracheoesophageal puncture (TEP) voice prosthesis.
  • Commonly done for advanced laryngeal carcinoma (T3/T4 stage).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: Incorrect.

 

  • Only part of the larynx is removed; airway continuity remains intact.
  • Voice is usually preserved, though may be hoarse.
  • No permanent stoma is created.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy: Incorrect.

 

  • A temporary airway created by puncturing trachea for ventilatory support in ICU patients.
  • The larynx remains intact; stoma closes after decannulation.

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: Incorrect.

 

  • A temporary or semi-permanent airway created below the larynx to relieve upper airway obstruction.
  • The patient can still phonate since airflow can pass through the larynx once decannulated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy involves complete removal of the larynx with permanent tracheostoma and loss of natural voice, used as definitive treatment for advanced laryngeal cancer.

choices.text: Injury to pleura during the procedure
Tube displacement creating a false passage
Tracheal stenosis secondary to mucosal injury

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent an emergency tracheostomy for upper airway obstruction. On the second postoperative day, he develops swelling and crepitus around the neck and upper chest. Palpation reveals a crackling sensation under the skin. His oxygen saturation remains stable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tube displacement creating a false passage

 

  • Subcutaneous emphysema after tracheostomy typically occurs due to air leakage into the soft tissues around the tracheostomy site.
  • This often results from tube displacement or creation of a false passage during reinsertion, allowing air to escape from the trachea into subcutaneous tissues instead of the airway.
  • Patients present with neck and chest swelling, palpable crepitus, and occasionally respiratory distress if extensive.
  • Management includes checking tube position, re-establishing airway, and avoiding high-pressure ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to pleura during the procedure: Incorrect.

 

  • This may cause pneumothorax, not subcutaneous emphysema alone.
  • Pneumothorax usually presents with respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds, not just crepitus around the neck.

 

Option B. Tube blockage due to secretions: Incorrect.

 

  • Leads to respiratory distress and hypoxia but does not cause air leakage or crepitus.

 

Option D. Tracheal stenosis secondary to mucosal injury: Incorrect.

 

  • A late complication of tracheostomy, occurring weeks to months later due to fibrosis, not in the immediate postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subcutaneous emphysema after tracheostomy is an intermediate complication caused by tube displacement or creation of a false passage, leading to air leakage into subcutaneous tissue with palpable crepitus on examination.

questions.text: A 35-year-old restaurant worker suddenly starts choking while eating meat. He is unable to speak or breathe, and is clutching his neck with both hands. You rush to help him and perform a series of quick, upward abdominal thrusts while standing behind him as shown. Which of the following maneuvers is being performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heimlich maneuver

 

  • The Heimlich maneuver (abdominal thrusts) is a life-saving first aid technique used to relieve foreign body airway obstruction in a conscious choking adult.
  • The rescuer stands behind the patient, places their arms around the victim’s abdomen, makes a fist just above the umbilicus, and delivers quick, upward thrusts toward the diaphragm.
  • The goal is to increase intra-thoracic pressure, forcing air from the lungs to expel the obstructing object.
  • It is contraindicated in infants (<1 year) — back blows and chest thrusts are preferred instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valsava maneuver: Incorrect.

 

  • Involves forced expiration against a closed glottis, commonly used in cardiac arrhythmias (like supraventricular tachycardia) to increase vagal tone, not for airway obstruction.

 

Option C. Sellick maneuver: Incorrect.

 

  • Also known as cricoid pressure, performed during intubation to prevent regurgitation and aspiration by compressing the esophagus.
  • It is not a choking relief maneuver.

 

Option D. Epley maneuver: Incorrect.

 

  • Used for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) to reposition otoliths within the semicircular canals, unrelated to airway obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver (abdominal thrusts) is the emergency procedure of choice for foreign body airway obstruction in a conscious adult, performed by delivering upward thrusts below the xiphoid process to expel the object by increasing intrathoracic pressure.

choices.text: Improve oxygen diffusion at alveolar level

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient with carcinoma of the larynx is planned for surgery. The anesthetist notes that he has severe upper airway obstruction with stridor. The surgeon decides to perform a tracheostomy before proceeding. Which of the following is not a valid indication for performing a tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Improve oxygen diffusion at alveolar level

 

  • Tracheostomy does not affect alveolar gas exchange directly. It only provides an alternate route for airflow to reach the lungs.
  • Oxygen diffusion at the alveolar-capillary membrane is determined by lung pathology, not airway patency.
  • Tracheostomy provides a direct airway to the trachea, bypassing obstructions at or above the larynx (e.g., tumors, trauma, edema, foreign bodies).
  • This is one of the most common emergency indications for tracheostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facilitate prolonged mechanical ventilation: Correct (Indication). In ICU patients requiring long-term ventilation (>10–14 days), tracheostomy reduces airway resistance, prevents laryngeal injury from endotracheal tubes, and facilitates weaning.

 

Option C. Prevent aspiration of oral secretions: Correct (Indication). Tracheostomy allows for better airway suctioning and clearance of secretions, reducing the risk of aspiration pneumonia, especially in neurologically impaired or comatose patients.

 

Educational Objective:

Tracheostomy is indicated for bypassing upper airway obstruction, facilitating prolonged ventilation, and aiding in secretion clearance, but it does not improve alveolar oxygen diffusion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He has severe maxillofacial trauma with profuse bleeding, tongue swelling, and complete upper airway obstruction. Endotracheal intubation fails due to distorted anatomy, and immediate airway access is required. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in airway management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroidotomy

 

  • Cricothyroidotomy (emergency airway or cricothyrotomy) is the procedure of choice in “can’t intubate, can’t ventilate” situations.
  • It involves making a transverse incision through the cricothyroid membrane (between the thyroid and cricoid cartilages) to provide rapid access to the trachea.
  • It is faster and easier to perform than a tracheostomy, requires minimal equipment, and is life-saving in upper airway obstruction (trauma, angioedema, foreign body).
  • However, it is contraindicated in children <12 years, as the larynx is small and injury to the cricoid cartilage may lead to subglottic stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: Incorrect.

 

  • Tracheostomy is not suitable for emergency airway access because it takes more time and requires dissection through multiple neck layers.
  • It is preferred for long-term airway management, not for immediate life-threatening obstruction.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal airway insertion: Incorrect.

 

  • This may help in partial obstructions caused by soft tissue collapse, but it is ineffective in complete upper airway obstruction (e.g., facial trauma, tongue swelling).

 

Option D. Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) placement: Incorrect.

 

  • LMA can be used in cases of difficult intubation, but it is contraindicated in massive facial trauma or complete upper airway blockage where the airway anatomy is distorted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cricothyroidotomy is the emergency surgical airway of choice in cases of acute upper airway obstruction or failed intubation, providing rapid access through the cricothyroid membrane to restore ventilation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sudden onset paroxysmal cough and biphasic stridor after playing with small toy parts. On auscultation, a palpable thud is noted over the trachea with each cough episode. Which of the following is the most likely site of airway obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trachea

 

  • Obstruction at the tracheal level causes biphasic stridor (heard in both inspiration and expiration) due to narrowing of the airway during both phases of respiration.
  • Cough paroxysms, falling drop sign (sudden cessation of cough when the foreign body drops), and palpable or audible thud are characteristic of tracheal foreign bodies.
  • Voice remains normal because the vocal cords are unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Larynx: Incorrect.

 

  • Laryngeal obstruction causes inspiratory stridor, voice change (hoarseness or aphonia), and severe respiratory distress because the obstruction is above the vocal cords.
  • Cough paroxysms and thud are not seen here.

 

Option C. Right main bronchus: Incorrect.

 

  • Bronchial obstruction causes localized wheeze or reduced air entry on one side without stridor or voice change.
  • Common in children due to the wider and more vertical right bronchus, but biphasic stridor is not a feature.

 

Option D. Left main bronchus: Incorrect.

 

  • Similar to right bronchial obstruction but less common due to the narrower and more horizontal left bronchus.
  • No stridor or voice change is observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biphasic stridor with cough paroxysms and a palpable thud indicates tracheal level obstruction, while laryngeal obstruction causes inspiratory stridor with voice change, and bronchial obstruction causes localized wheeze without stridor or voice change.

choices.text: Begin chest compressions as in CPR
Deliver 5 back blows followed by 5 chest thrusts
Attempt blind finger sweep to remove the object

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant suddenly begins to choke while feeding and becomes cyanotic. The child is conscious but unable to cry or cough effectively. What is the most appropriate immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deliver 5 back blows followed by 5 chest thrusts

 

  • For infants <1 year who are conscious but choking, the recommended maneuver is alternating 5 back slaps (between the shoulder blades) with 5 chest thrusts (at the lower half of the sternum).
  • This generates pressure to expel the foreign body while minimizing risk of internal injury.
  • The process is repeated until the airway is cleared or the infant becomes unresponsive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver): Incorrect.

 

  • Abdominal thrusts are used for children ≥1 year and adults, not infants.
  • In infants, this maneuver risks injuring abdominal organs (especially the liver).

 

Option B. Begin chest compressions as in CPR: Incorrect.

 

  • Chest compressions are indicated only when the infant becomes unresponsive, i.e., no breathing or pulse.
  • For a responsive choking infant, back blows and chest thrusts are done first.

 

Option D. Attempt blind finger sweep to remove the object: Incorrect.

 

  • Blind finger sweeps can push the foreign body deeper into the airway, worsening obstruction.
  • You should remove an object only if it is visible during airway inspection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a responsive choking infant (<1 year), the correct immediate management is alternating 5 back slaps and 5 chest thrusts, while for children ≥1-year, abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) are performed.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy undergoes a tonsillectomy for recurrent tonsillitis. Six hours after surgery, he suddenly begins to cough up bright red blood and becomes restless. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reactionary hemorrhage from slipped ligature

 

  • Occurs within 6–24 hours after tonsillectomy due to slipped ligature or rise in BP.
  • The patient in this scenario had sudden bright red bleeding 6 hours post-op, fitting this description.

 

Tonsillectomy hemorrhage is classified based on timing of onset:

 

  1. Primary hemorrhage – occurs intraoperatively or within the first 24 hours (usually within 6 hours).
    • Cause: Inadequate hemostasis during surgery.
    • Type of blood: Bright red, active bleeding.
    • Management: Return to OT for re-ligation or cauterization.
  2. Reactionary hemorrhage – occurs within 6–24 hours post-op (most commonly around 6 hours).
    • Cause: Slipped ligature, rise in BP after anesthesia, or clot dislodgement.
    • Characteristic: Sudden bright-red bleeding after initial stable recovery.
    • Management: Immediate airway protection and return to OR for control.
  3. Secondary hemorrhage – occurs 5–10 days post-surgery.
    • Cause: Infection of the tonsillar fossa during sloughing of the eschar.
    • Blood: Dark, mixed with slough.
    • Management: IV antibiotics, and control of bleeding if active.
  •  

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary hemorrhage: Incorrect. Occurs days later (5–10 days) due to infection and sloughing, not within hours.

 

Option C. Primary hemorrhage: Incorrect. Occurs during surgery or immediately after, not after several hours.

 

Option D. Bleeding from the adenoid bed: Incorrect. Seen after adenoidectomy, not tonsillectomy.

 

Educational Objective:
