Reactionary hemorrhage after tonsillectomy occurs within 6–24 hours, most commonly due to slipped ligature or rise in blood pressure, and presents as sudden bright red bleeding requiring urgent surgical control.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with persistent dull ear pain on the right side for the past 3 weeks. Otoscopic examination of the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane appears normal. On further evaluation, he complains of pain and discomfort while swallowing. There is ulcerative growth over the right tonsillar fossa on oropharyngeal examination. Which cranial nerve is most likely responsible for this referred ear pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

 

Referred otalgia occurs because the ear shares sensory innervation with several cranial and cervical nerves. The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) supplies:

 

  • The middle ear and Eustachian tube via the tympanic branch (Jacobson’s nerve), and
  • The posterior one-third of the tongue, tonsil, and oropharynx.

 

Hence, diseases of the tonsil, base of tongue, or pharynx (such as tonsillar carcinoma or pharyngitis) can refer pain to the ear through the tympanic branch of CN IX even when the ear itself is normal.

 

  • Supplies the tonsil, posterior tongue, and middle ear (via Jacobson’s nerve).
  • Pathology in the tonsil or oropharynx (as in this case) commonly refers pain to the ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve (CN V): Incorrect.

 

  • Referred otalgia via the auriculotemporal branch of CN V occurs in dental infections, TMJ disorders, or parotid gland disease.
  • The pain is typically anterior or preauricular, not associated with swallowing.

 

Option C. Vagus nerve (CN X): Incorrect.

 

  • The auricular branch (Arnold’s nerve) supplies the external auditory canal and concha.
  • Referred otalgia via CN X occurs in laryngeal, hypopharyngeal, or esophageal pathologies (e.g., carcinoma of the larynx).

 

Option D. Facial nerve (CN VII): Incorrect.

 

  • The posterior auricular branch of CN VII supplies part of the auricle.
  • Lesions like Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) cause painful vesicular eruptions, not referred pain from throat lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia due to tonsillar or oropharyngeal lesions occurs via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) through its tympanic branch (Jacobson’s nerve), which carries sensory fibers to the middle ear and tonsillar region.

choices.text: Perform a punch biopsy for histopathological diagnosis
Schedule an angiography followed by preoperative embolization and surgical excision
Begin intranasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation
Administer antifungal therapy for suspected invasive sinus disease

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with recurrent, profuse, spontaneous epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction for the past 6 months. On examination, a smooth, lobulated, reddish mass is seen filling the nasopharynx and extending into the nasal cavity. The mass bleeds on touch. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule an angiography followed by preoperative embolization and surgical excision

 

  • This is the standard management.
  • Angiography helps map vascular supply, and embolization reduces intraoperative blood loss before definitive surgical removal.

 

The case describes a teenage boy with recurrent epistaxis and a highly vascular nasopharyngeal mass, characteristic of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) — a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor arising from the sphenopalatine foramen region.

 

  • Biopsy is contraindicated, as the tumor is highly vascular and can cause massive hemorrhage.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed radiologically using CT/MRI and angiography, which also helps identify the feeding vessels (typically the internal maxillary artery, a branch of the external carotid artery).
  • Preoperative embolization minimizes bleeding risk during surgical excision, which remains the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform a punch biopsy: Incorrect. Never biopsy a suspected JNA. It can lead to catastrophic bleeding due to the tumor’s vascular nature.

 

Option C. Intranasal corticosteroids: Incorrect. Steroids have no role in JNA. The mass is vascular, not inflammatory, and will not regress with medication.

 

Option D. Antifungal therapy: Incorrect. Antifungal treatment is used for fungal sinusitis, which does not present with recurrent, profuse epistaxis or a lobulated vascular mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but highly vascular tumor seen in adolescent males, presenting with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction; biopsy is contraindicated, and management involves angiography with preoperative embolization followed by surgical excision.

choices.text: Immediate incision and drainage with IV antibiotics
Needle aspiration followed by tonsillectomy in the same sitting

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with severe sore throat, painful swallowing, and fever for 4 days. He also complains of difficulty opening his mouth and a “hot potato” voice. On examination, his uvula is deviated to the left, and there is a bulge in the right peritonsillar area with tender cervical lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate incision and drainage with IV antibiotics

 

  • The standard initial treatment of quinsy.
  • Drainage relieves pain, improves trismus, and prevents spread of infection (e.g., to parapharyngeal space).

 

This patient has Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess) — a suppurative complication of tonsillitis, typically caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus. It is characterized by:

 

  • Unilateral peritonsillar swelling (bulge in anterior pillar),
  • Uvula deviation to the opposite side,
  • Trismus (difficulty opening mouth),
  • “Hot potato” voice, and
  • Severe odynophagia (painful swallowing).

 

Management involves:

 

  1. Drainage of abscess (by needle aspiration, incision & drainage, or quinsy tonsillectomy).
  2. IV antibiotics covering streptococci and anaerobes.
  3. Hydration and pain relief.
  4. Elective interval tonsillectomy after 6–8 weeks may be considered to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate: Incorrect.

 

  • Oral antibiotics alone are ineffective, as the infection is localized and walled off.
  • Antibiotics are adjuncts to drainage, not replacements.

 

Option C. Needle aspiration followed by tonsillectomy in the same sitting: Incorrect.

 

  • Needle aspiration may confirm pus, but same-sitting tonsillectomy (Quinsy tonsillectomy) is reserved for recurrent tonsillitis or bilateral abscess, not as a routine first step.

 

Option D. Warm saline gargles and observation: Incorrect.

 

  • This approach is suitable for peritonsillar cellulitis, not for an established abscess.
  • Delay can lead to airway obstruction or parapharyngeal abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quinsy (Peritonsillar abscess) presents with unilateral throat pain, trismus, uvular deviation, and “hot potato” voice; management requires immediate incision and drainage with IV antibiotics to prevent airway compromise and deep neck spread.

choices.text: Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex medial → Lateral geniculate body → Inferior colliculus
Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex inferior → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior geniculate body
Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex superior → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus
Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex lateral → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. An MRI of the internal auditory canal reveals bilateral vestibular schwannomas. The attending asks a medical student to explain the correct sequence of the auditory pathway involved in processing sound impulses from the cochlea to the auditory cortex. Which of the following options represents the correct order?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex superior → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus

 

The auditory pathway transmits sound impulses from the cochlea to the auditory cortex in a well-defined relay sequence through brainstem nuclei and midbrain structures. The correct order is:

 

Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex (temporal lobe)

 

  • The cochlear nucleus receives input from the cochlear nerve (CN VIII).
  • The superior olivary complex is the first structure to receive bilateral input, essential for sound localization.
  • The lateral lemniscus acts as a fiber tract carrying signals to the inferior colliculus, which integrates auditory information.
  • The inferior colliculus then projects to the medial geniculate body (thalamus), which finally relays signals to the auditory cortex (area 41, 42) in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex medial → Lateral geniculate body → Inferior colliculus: Incorrect.

 

  • The lateral geniculate body is part of the visual pathway, not auditory.
  • The auditory relay involves the medial geniculate body.

 

Option B. Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex inferior → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior geniculate body: Incorrect.

 

  • There is no inferior olivary complex in the auditory pathway (that belongs to the medulla and is related to cerebellar circuits).
  • The correct auditory relay nucleus is the superior olivary complex.

 

Option D. Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex lateral → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex: Incorrect.

 

  • The lateral olivary nucleus is a part of the superior olivary complex but not the next major relay station.
  • The pathway must pass through the lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus before reaching the medial geniculate body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auditory pathway follows the sequence — Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex, enabling precise localization and perception of sound.

choices.text: Stenson’s duct travels upward against gravity
Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands

questions.text: Sialolithiasis is most common in submandibular gland because:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands

 

  • Submandibular saliva is mucin-rich and viscous, leading to stagnation and stone formation.

 

Also, higher calcium and phosphate content favors crystallization.

 

Sialolithiasis (salivary gland stone) most commonly affects the submandibular gland (Wharton’s duct), accounting for 80–90% of cases. This predilection is due to both anatomical and physiological factors:

 

  1. Nature of secretion:
    • The submandibular gland produces mixed serous and mucous secretions, which are thicker and more alkaline, predisposing to precipitation of calcium salts and formation of calculi.
  2. Duct anatomy:
    • Wharton’s duct is long, tortuous, and runs upward against gravity from the gland to the oral cavity, slowing the flow of saliva and increasing stasis.

 

However, among the options given, the key determinant mentioned is the thicker secretion, hence Option B is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stenson’s duct travels up against gravity: Incorrect.

 

  • Stenson’s duct belongs to the parotid gland, not the submandibular gland.
  • It opens opposite the upper 2nd molar tooth and does not explain submandibular stones.

 

Option C. Both A and B: Incorrect.

 

  • The first statement is wrong (refers to the wrong duct).
  • Only the viscosity of secretions contributes here.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect.

 

  • Option B correctly identifies the main cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sialolithiasis most commonly affects the submandibular gland because its viscous, mucous-rich secretions and long, tortuous duct predispose to stagnation and calculus formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with chronic sore throat and recurrent tonsillar pain for several months. On examination, the tonsils appear enlarged with deep crypts. On gentle pressure over the tonsillar surface, a cheesy, foul-smelling material exudes from the crypts. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Irwin-Moore sign

 

  • Seen in chronic tonsillitis, due to chronic infection and crypt hypertrophy leading to retention of caseous material.
  • Irwin-Moore sign is a classical feature of chronic tonsillitis, characterized by the expression of cheesy, caseous, or purulent material from the tonsillar crypts on gentle pressure.
  • This material represents debris composed of epithelial cells, bacteria, and food particles, which accumulate in enlarged crypts due to chronic inflammation.
  • It produces a fetid odor and contributes to halitosis (bad breath) — a typical symptom of chronic tonsillitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foul-smelling exudate sign: Incorrect. Descriptive but not an eponymous clinical sign. The correct name for this finding is Irwin-Moore sign.

 

Option C. Cahan’s sign: Incorrect. Cahan’s sign refers to pain radiating to the ear (referred otalgia) in carcinoma of the larynx, not a feature of tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Eagle’s sign: Incorrect. Related to Eagle’s syndrome, where elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament causes throat and referred ear pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irwin-Moore sign is the expression of cheesy, caseous material from tonsillar crypts on pressure, seen in chronic tonsillitis due to cryptic debris and chronic infection.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with unilateral hardness of hearing and ear block sensation. Rinne was negative on affected side. Cone of light was absent and handle of malleus was foreshortened. On impedance audiometry, which of the following type of curve is most likely to appear?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

  • Type C (Correct): Peak shifted to negative pressure—Eustachian tube dysfunction with retraction.
  • The exam findings (absent cone of light, foreshortened malleus handle) indicate TM retraction from negative middle-ear pressure due to Eustachian tube dysfunction. 
  • This causes a conductive hearing loss (Rinne negative) and produces a Type C tympanogram—a peak of compliance shifted to negative pressure (typically < –100 daPa).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Type A (Normal): Normal peak at ~0 daPa; middle-ear pressure and mobility are normal—not consistent with retracted TM and CHL.

 

Option B. Type B (Flat): Little/no peak; suggests middle-ear effusion, perforation with large EAC volume, or wax with small volume—classically OME, not just negative pressure.

 

Option D. Type Ad (Deep): Hypercompliant TM/ossicular discontinuity (very tall peak); would not fit the retraction signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eustachian tube dysfunction with TM retraction causes conductive hearing loss and yields a Type C tympanogram (peak at negative pressure).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman sustains a temporal bone fracture. During surgery, the surgeon notes the semicircular canals and vestibule. Which two semicircular canals unite to form a crus commune before opening into the vestibule?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior and posterior semicircular canals

 

Superior and posterior semicircular canals: Correct. Their non-ampullated limbs join to form the crus commune, which opens into the vestibule.

 

The crus commune (common crus) is formed by the union of the non-ampullated limbs of the superior (anterior) and posterior semicircular canals before they open into the vestibule.

 

Each semicircular canal has two limbs (crura) — one with an ampulla (ampullated) and one without (non-ampullated).

 

  • The lateral semicircular canal opens into the vestibule separately and does not contribute to the crus commune.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superior and lateral semicircular canals: Incorrect. They lie in different planes and do not unite.

 

Option C. Posterior and lateral semicircular canals: Incorrect. Both open independently into the vestibule.

 

Option D. All three semicircular canals: Incorrect. Only two canals (superior and posterior) unite; lateral remains separate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The crus commune is formed by the union of the non-ampullated limbs of the superior and posterior semicircular canals before opening into the vestibule.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A3, B4, C1, D2

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kero’s – cribriform plate; Tos – pars flaccida retraction; Sade – pars tensa retraction; Cotton–Meyer – subglottic stenosis.

choices.text: True positive fistula test indicates perilymph fistula
False positive fistula test indicates congenital syphilis
True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease
False negative fistula test indicates dead labyrinth

questions.text: Find the false statement among the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) True negative fistula test indicates late stages of Ménière’s disease

 

  • In late-stage Ménière’s, fibrosis may fix the labyrinth, but sometimes residual fibrous attachments between the membranous labyrinth and footplate can mimic a false positive (Hennebert’s sign).
  • Hence, true negative is not typical for late-stage Ménière’s — the labyrinth may still respond abnormally (false positive).

 

The fistula test is used to detect perilymphatic fistula or labyrinthine erosion, particularly over the lateral semicircular canal, as in cholesteatoma.


Pressure over the tragus or via Siegel’s pneumatic speculum changes middle ear pressure; if this stimulates the labyrinth (abnormally connected), the patient experiences vertigo and nystagmus — a positive fistula sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True positive fistula test indicates perilymph fistula: True.

 

  • A true positive result occurs when there is a real perilymphatic communication, e.g., due to cholesteatoma erosion of the lateral semicircular canal.
  • Mechanism: Pressure → perilymph movement → cupula deflection → vertigo & nystagmus.
  • Also called circumscribed labyrinthitis when limited to one canal.

 

Option B. False positive fistula test indicates congenital syphilis: True.

 

  • Seen in Hennebert’s sign – a false positive response (no actual fistula).
  • Mechanism: Hypermobile stapes footplate or fibrous adhesions between the membranous labyrinth and stapes footplate cause abnormal vestibular stimulation.
  • Seen in congenital syphilis and few late Ménière’s disease cases.

 

Option D. False negative fistula test indicates dead labyrinth: True. 

 

  • When the labyrinth is completely non-functional (e.g., after suppurative labyrinthitis), pressure changes do not elicit any response even if a fistula exists.
  • This is termed a false negative result.

 

Educational Objective:

 

False negative fistula test occurs in a dead labyrinth or when cholesteatoma covers the fistula; false positive (Hennebert’s sign) occurs in congenital syphilis or late Ménière’s disease due to abnormal stapes-footplate movement.
